data.text: Ok. But why? You can't just put the same bags in your rear rack and be more stable?
data.author: Kleanthis Kokavesis

data.text: it‚Äôs all the debate between pro and against trailer. If you decide to take a heavy load and you put the heavier things under the center of the wheel the handling in rough trail will be better. Check how long are the trailer bag. I will need a way longer chainstay or a special rack to do the same thing. Other considerations for me. All the essential things are on the bike. I just undo and hide the trailer and can going in light multiple day trail trip. It‚Äôs my system for a one year travel of bikepacking and climbing. I don‚Äôt think we can have a clear good and bad ways. It depends what you want to do.
data.author: Frederic Dumoulin

data.text: Why?
data.author: Bernd Paul

data.text: I used an early single wheel for half of my tour around the UK. I came to the conclusion it was more trouble than it was worth. The panniers are too low slung and tended to catch on anything above about 4 inches high. It seriously increases the turning circle and for me just became another bit of unnecessary kit. I got fed up with lugging it behind me uphill where it felt like an anchor. It also made my front wheel feel very light. It needs to be well balanced to prevent fishtailing on fast downhills which is not a pleasant experience. I ended my journey with 4 panniers and a rack pack. Oh and whilst training the left hand pannier hit a bank and I ended up over the handlebars. Each to their own but I feel it's an over complicated solution.
data.author: Michael Cope

data.text: Here a picture of the Voyager pro trailer at the left and the Mate at the right. to test the concept we take a heavy load in a nasty trail in purpose. It‚Äôs funny because your description of a trailer is what we lived with the voyager pro. Too low, too instable. She destroyed his panier in this trip. And yes even for the Mate you need to balance the weight in the trailer and have the good weight on the front wheel. I agree stay with the four panier unless you want big load and trail capacity.
data.author: Frederic Dumoulin

data.text: it did have a pretty flag on it though. ü§£ü§£ü§£
data.author: Michael Cope

data.text: I've read several accounts by people who shed their trailer weight.
data.author: Mike Dannheim

data.text: it seemed like a good idea and I kinda fell for the hype and I'd bought it so I was bloody well going to use it. It was my first big tour and like a lot of people I was carrying far too much stuff. (4 panniers plus the trailer) But eventually I learned. We used to have a saying; (keep it simple stupid).
data.author: Michael Cope

data.text: I can relate to your comment about panniers being too low slung. It's the first time I've seen anyone mention this issue but on my very first tour I managed to scuff a hole in one of my brand new Ortlieb panniers, but on the fork, rather than a trailer. I was riding through a northern Japanese city, where the concrete curbs are extra high to cope with winter snow and my left side pannier brushed against the curb. Low centre of gravity is, of course, desirable but I'll be changing my low slung front pannier rack for something that mounts panniers a little higher off the road for the next trip.
data.author: Paul McMahon

data.text: that's what bodge tape was invented for. üòÇ
data.author: Michael Cope

data.text: I use Burley's Travoy trailer as a utility bike cargo trailer. I find it has an uncanny tendency to feel like it's not even there. I wonder if it would work on a bike tour.
data.author: Matthew Leo

data.text: I'm sure it will in the right conditions, I just find it hampers manoeuvrability in certain circumstances such as certain types of gates and even lifts where I had to faff about disconnecting it just to get in and out. As. Someone pointed out, for deliveries and cargo they are perfect. It's also another potential puncture or mechanical failure. Can you tell I'm not a fan? üòÑ
data.author: Michael Cope

data.text: I too thought this was a perfect solution to my needs, but for all the reasons you mentioned I abandoned it after a few trial runs. It took all my concentration to just keep everything upright and the curbs pretty much destroyed the right site pannier. I'll be selling mine, but not so sure I'll be able to find a buyer.
data.author: Brett Mitchell

data.text: I eventually used the wheel to replace my front wheel which was worn out. I changed the flag and tied it to my rear rack. I left the rest with a friend and I never saw it again. I suppose I could have sold it but I didn't care really. It was an interesting experiment but not one I'm likely to repeat.
data.author: Michael Cope

data.text: same here.
data.author: Brett Mitchell

data.text: I hated the way it just fell over when you took it off. Small point I know but on a long trip it grates after a while.
data.author: Michael Cope

data.text: yes indeed. The other thing that caused me a problem was that it Interfered with my derailleur if I took a good dip in a pothole.
data.author: Brett Mitchell

data.text: The more storage space you have the more kit you haul... Just keep things small and simple is my advice.
data.author: Alan Lane

data.text: absolutely true! in my case we need the space for medical supplies.
data.author: Freerk de Boer
Daniel Busanszky

data.text: Skip the wheel and get a Burley coho. More space to put stuff üòâ
data.author: Lars Miller

data.text: Do some touring with conventional pannier set up first to see if that serves you well before purchasing a trailer .The more gear the heavier the load .Keep it simple .
data.author: Grant McKern

data.text: If it was an electric unicycle, it might be interesting.
data.author: Anne Elle Vistingue

data.text: I have the voyager pro. I found it useful to use with a bike not designed for bike Touring. I had my heavy stuff on the extrawheel and 2 small panniers on my bike. It handles fairly well and have a added bonus of beeing odd enough that motorists notice you. My only real downside is that it is a hassle to pack for flights. I managed to get my bike and the extrawheel in a huge cardboard bikebox, but it was a lot of work. For more local trips I have no complaints
